choices.C: Interface GigabitEthernet 0/0. The tie breaker of the node index priority is lower and trumps the path cost.
choices.A: Interface GigabitEthernet 0/0. The tie breaker of the path cost being lower. The node index priority does not impact this selection process.
choices.D: Interface GigabitEthernet 0/1. The tie breaker of the node index priority is lower and trumps the path cost.
choices.B: Interface GigabitEthernet 0/1. The tie breaker of the path cost being lower. The node index priority does not impact this selection process.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Cost wins, tiebreaker is for ties.

choices.C: A reserved BGP community of 1:10 must be used to denote the PIC feature set to the routing protocol
choices.D: BGP import/export policies must be applied on all devices for the routes needing BGP for PIC
choices.A: Bidirectional Forwarding Detection must be applied to the upstream facing BGP interfaces
choices.B: The operator must ensure that all prefixes have the same next-hop from PE1 and PE2 for BGP PIC

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network operator is configuring BGP PIC on CE1 on already established neighborships with PE1 and PE2 inside the fully converged MPLS network. Which element needs to be implemented to make this feature function effectively?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The Level-1 Area ends at R4 and R3. Keep in mind that default metric in ISIS is 10. So the link R1 to R4 is 10. R1-R2-R3 is 16. So R4 is the better exit. When changing R1-R2 to metric 1, the total metric to the exit point R3 is 9 and now preferred.

Selected Answer: C
Correct is C

choices.C: Change the link metric for the link from router R1 to router R2 to 1.
choices.A: Configure all routers as Level 1 routers.
choices.B: Remove the link metric for the link from router R1 to router R2.
choices.D: Configure all routers as Level 1 / Level 2 routers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
If Segments Left is zero, the node must ignore the Routing header
 and proceed to process the next header in the packet, whose type
 is identified by the Next Header field in the Routing header.

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2460#section-4.7

questions.question_text: A network operator working for a telecommunication company with an employee id: 4074:92:707 is planning to implement the Nonstop Forwarding (NSR) feature on the customerâ€™s core network. After getting the configuration ready for NSR. on which router should the operator implement NSR changes?
